entry.title: Basecamp Moving Out Of The Cloud
entry.content: I generally don’t like to repost DHH, but I saw this morning that Basecamp is moving out of the AWS Cloud because it’s not cost effective for them. For those of y’all who have read my Cloudbusting and Cloud Strategy Guide articles, this should sound familiar.

entry.title: Run Your Own Social Network
entry.content: With the implosion of Twitter, it’s a good time to revisit this post from Darius Kazemi on some of the philsophical aspects of running a Mastodon (or Hometown) server for your friends & colleagues!

entry.title: Astronomer Ranks Fictional Spaceships
entry.content: H/t Gareth Branwyn on BoingBoing: Michael Siegel reviews the most popular spaceships from Sci-Fi and rates them. Super-nerdy and fun.

entry.title: Animated Gifs
entry.content: There is little in this world that I love more than animated gifs, especially those crunchy oldschool ones. @hachx0 notes that GearSphere has shared a thriftstore CD full of them!

entry.title: <blink> Polyfill
entry.content: Gareth Branwyn and Ben Morris said my site wasn’t properly retro unless I had the <blink> tag, but that’s deprecated so I wrote a polyfill. Who doesn’t love a good challenge?

entry.title: Civic tech has lost its way...again
entry.content: Angelica Quicksey put out this compelling assessment of the current state of civic tech. A must-read, particularly for Federal staff.

entry.title: The 21st of September (Demi Adejuyigbe)
entry.content: Last year Demi Adejuyigbe announced the end of his wonderful series of annual videos celebrating September 21st and Earth, Wind & Fire. But we can still celebrate today by revisiting all six of those delights!

entry.title: Tasneem Kabir Ceramics
entry.content: I met this wonderful potter today at the Brookland pottery festival, he uses traditional Islamic patterns. I had to purchase this beautiful piece immediately! Check out his other work!

entry.title: Civic Chill
entry.content: I love this idea from Peter, the concept of “Civic Chill” and how to embrace it in public interest tech work.

entry.title: Hackers Day!
entry.content: Friends, it is my favorite holiday: #HackersDay! It’s a day to hack something, whether it’s code, policy, or bureaucracy! You can follow along on Twitter as I share media and resources about hacking! #HackThePlanet!

entry.title: Nona the Ninth
entry.content: Space Necromancers! The third book in the Locked Tomb Series just dropped. The first two were some of the best sci-fi/fantasy I’ve read in a long while.

entry.title: Popula: Chicago City Bureau
entry.content: This interview with Darryl Holliday about free, public, local media is incredibly compelling. A very interesting civic model.

entry.title: 10 Years with Hayao Miyazaki
entry.content: NHK has a free documentary about the head of Studio Ghibli (Princess Mononoke, Spirited Away, Howl’s Moving Castle, etc.). Not as fun as his movies, but I enjoy his curmudgeonly charm.

entry.title: Zelda: Link to the Past Romhacks
entry.content: Feeling nostalgic for this 1992 classic game? Folks have created remixed versions that are fantastic. I’m enjoying Parallel Remodel but it’s very hard!

entry.title: Tone Tags
entry.content: I had seen /s for sarcasm in messages, but I didn’t know there’s a whole library of these! Very helpful for improving accessibility!

entry.title: China's Bike-Share Graveyards
entry.content: I’m a huge fan of bike-shares, and was saddened to see this photo essay on failed bike-share programs in China.

entry.title: IT Project Scope
entry.content: Great article from Sean Boots on sizing IT projects to run between leadership turnover cycles.

entry.title: The Landscape of GovTech Work
entry.content: I’ve been sharing this article from Pluribus Digital with folks a lot lately, it’s a great summary of how to get into government work.
